content: From CS Monitor: Reagan and Gorbachev agreed to fight UFOs By Jimmy Orr | 04.24.09 This is a perfect one for Friday night. Charlie Rose had the former president of the Soviet Union Mikhail Gorbachev and President Reagan’s Secretary of State George Shultz on his program this past Tuesday night. This year marks the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall. Gorbachev got a laugh when he said he wasn’t all that impressed with Reagan’s historic challenge to “tear down this wall”. But went on to say that he believed Reagan “was a great president.” Shultz was talking about the Lake Geneva summit and mentioned the two leaders ducked out of a meeting to take a walk to a nearby cabin. “I wasn’t there…,” Shultz said before Gorbachev cut him off. “From the fireside house, President Reagan suddenly said to me, ‘What would you do if the United States were suddenly attacked by someone from outer space? Would you help us?’ “I said, ‘No doubt about it.’” “He said, ‘We too.’” “So that’s interesting,” Gorbachev said to much laughter. He then said to Shultz, “I’m sorry for having interrupted you, but it was an interesting moment.” Rose concurred.
reply: From CS Monitor: Reagan and Gorbachev agreed to fight UFOs By Jimmy Orr | 04.24.09 This is a perfect one for Friday night. Charlie Rose had the former president of the Soviet Union Mikhail Gorbachev and President Reagan’s Secretary of State George Shultz on his program this past Tuesday night. This year marks the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall. Gorbachev got a laugh when he said he wasn’t all that impressed with Reagan’s historic challenge to “tear down this wall”. But went on to say that he believed Reagan “was a great president.” Shultz was talking about the Lake Geneva summit and mentioned the two leaders ducked out of a meeting to take a walk to a nearby cabin. “I wasn’t there…,” Shultz said before Gorbachev cut him off. “From the fireside house, President Reagan suddenly said to me, ‘What would you do if the United States were suddenly attacked by someone from outer space? Would you help us?’ “I said, ‘No doubt about it.’” “He said, ‘We too.’” “So that’s interesting,” Gorbachev said to much laughter. He then said to Shultz, “I’m sorry for having interrupted you, but it was an interesting moment.” Rose concurred.
title: You mean a senile American DIDN'T tear down the wall?

title: You mean a senile American DIDN'T tear down the wall?

content: Gorbachev policies and agreeably should not be discounted. It could not have happen without him. The Soviets trusted conservative leadership, like Nixon and Reagan's. (USSR was not liberal, it was conservative, too.) They were very leery of liberals. The timing was right, it fit into Gorbachev's policies to get a 'human face' back on the scheme of Communism. And get the USSR check-book out of the Eastern Block nations. Anyway... the real surprise for the followers of conservationism (Reagan, etc.) was the total near to non-violent fall of the Soviet system. None of those folks saw it coming... but some of us scholars did here and over there. I was a US adviser to the Soviet Academy of Science, US and Canadian Studies at that time and those folks knew it was coming. The question was how far would the crumble go..... they didn't expect it to go so far as the dissolution of the entire CCCP "state". Anyway, there are many forces at work in this scenario. With or without Reagan the wall would have come down.
reply: Gorbachev policies and agreeably should not be discounted. It could not have happen without him. The Soviets trusted conservative leadership, like Nixon and Reagan's. With or without Reagan the wall would have come down.

content: So President Reagan was just "a senile American"? Disgusting. As for the "UFO" chit, that's nothing but hearsay decades after this meeting and it doesn't matter one way or the other whether it's true. It's hardly proof that Reagan was "senile" at that time.
reply: So President Reagan was just "a senile American"? Disgusting. As for the "UFO" chit, that's nothing but hearsay decades after this meeting and it doesn't matter one way or the other whether it's true. It's hardly proof that Reagan was "senile" at that time.
title: You mean a senile American DIDN'T tear down the wall?

content: quote: Originally posted by shades_of_grey: So President Reagan was just "a senile American"? Disgusting. As for the "UFO" chit, that's nothing but hearsay decades after this meeting and it doesn't matter one way or the other whether it's true. It's hardly proof that Reagan was "senile" at that time. He probably was not 'senile' at that time, but he did say, publicly, in Red Square, Moscow, USSR, to Mr. Gorbachev, "I wish we had a common enemy to bring us together, maybe in outer space." It's hard to tell if Reagan was serious, ..or what he really meant (it could have been their little 'joke' between them) but he did say it, so I suppose he said what he did in private to Gorbachev. Gorbachev would have no reason to lie about it... not now.

It's hard to tell if Reagan was serious, ..or what he really meant (it could have been their little 'joke' between them) but he did say it, so I suppose he said what he did in private to Gorbachev. Gorbachev would have no reason to lie about it... not now.

content: The leaders of the Soviet Union were not conservative in the sense that they believe in a free market, etc. They were conservative in the sense that they were distrustful of change, and valued the status quo. What Gorbachev, who was much more conservative than people think, realized and expressed was that the status quo was no longer possible. He did not expect, nor want, the revolution that happened. He wanted to reform what already existed in order to allow the soviet state to continue. Reagan, while probably the best president of our lifetimes, was most certainly not the best president in our nation's history. George Washington created the presidency through sheer personality and discretion, making himself "first citizen" and preventing the executive from falling into something akin to monarchy, which many citizens in his time actually wanted.
reply: The leaders of the Soviet Union were not conservative in the sense that they believe in a free market, etc. They were conservative in the sense that they were distrustful of change, and valued the status quo. I was a US adviser to the Soviet Academy of Science, US and Canadian Studies at that time and those folks knew it was coming. The question was how far would the crumble go..... they didn't expect it to go so far as the dissolution of the entire CCCP "state". Anyway, there are many forces at work in this scenario. With or without Reagan the wall would have come down.
title: You mean a senile American DIDN'T tear down the wall?

content: So President Reagan was just "a senile American"? Disgusting. As for the "UFO" chit, that's nothing but hearsay decades after this meeting and it doesn't matter one way or the other whether it's true. It's hardly proof that Reagan was "senile" at that time.
reply: So President Reagan was just "a senile American"? Disgusting. As for the "UFO" chit, that's nothing but hearsay decades after this meeting and it doesn't matter one way or the other whether it's true. It's hardly proof that Reagan was "senile" at that time.
title: You mean a senile American DIDN'T tear down the wall?

content: quote: Originally posted by shades_of_grey: So President Reagan was just "a senile American"? Disgusting. As for the "UFO" chit, that's nothing but hearsay decades after this meeting and it doesn't matter one way or the other whether it's true. It's hardly proof that Reagan was "senile" at that time. He probably was not 'senile' at that time, but he did say, publicly, in Red Square, Moscow, USSR, to Mr. Gorbachev, "I wish we had a common enemy to bring us together, maybe in outer space." It's hard to tell if Reagan was serious, ..or what he really meant (it could have been their little 'joke' between them) but he did say it, so I suppose he said what he did in private to Gorbachev. Gorbachev would have no reason to lie about it... not now.

content: The leaders of the Soviet Union were not conservative in the sense that they believe in a free market, etc. They were conservative in the sense that they were distrustful of change, and valued the status quo. What Gorbachev, who was much more conservative than people think, realized and expressed was that the status quo was no longer possible. He did not expect, nor want, the revolution that happened. He wanted to reform what already existed in order to allow the soviet state to continue. Reagan, while probably the best president of our lifetimes, was most certainly not the best president in our nation's history. George Washington created the presidency through sheer personality and discretion, making himself "first citizen" and preventing the executive from falling into something akin to monarchy, which many citizens in his time actually wanted.
reply: The leaders of the Soviet Union were not conservative in the sense that they believe in a free market, etc. They were conservative in the sense that they were distrustful of change, and valued the status quo. content: From CS Monitor: Reagan and Gorbachev agreed to fight UFOs By Jimmy Orr | 04.24.09 This is a perfect one for Friday night. Charlie Rose had the former president of the Soviet Union Mikhail Gorbachev and President Reagan’s Secretary of State George Shultz on his program this past Tuesday night. This year marks the 20th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall. Gorbachev got a laugh when he said he wasn’t all that impressed with Reagan’s historic challenge to “tear down this wall”. But went on to say that he believed Reagan “was a great president.” Shultz was talking about the Lake Geneva summit and mentioned the two leaders ducked out of a meeting to take a walk to a nearby cabin. “I wasn’t there…,” Shultz said before Gorbachev cut him off. “From the fireside house, President Reagan suddenly said to me, ‘What would you do if the United States were suddenly attacked by someone from outer space? Would you help us?’ “I said, ‘No doubt about it.’” “He said, ‘We too.’” “So that’s interesting,” Gorbachev said to much laughter. He then said to Shultz, “I’m sorry for having interrupted you, but it was an interesting moment.” Rose concurred.

But went on to say that he believed Reagan “was a great president.” Shultz was talking about the Lake Geneva summit and mentioned the two leaders ducked out of a meeting to take a walk to a nearby cabin. “I wasn’t there…,” Shultz said before Gorbachev cut him off. “From the fireside house, President Reagan suddenly said to me, ‘What would you do if the United States were suddenly attacked by someone from outer space? Would you help us?’ “I said, ‘No doubt about it.’” “He said, ‘We too.’” “So that’s interesting,” Gorbachev said to much laughter. He then said to Shultz, “I’m sorry for having interrupted you, but it was an interesting moment.” Rose concurred.

content: Gorbachev policies and agreeably should not be discounted. It could not have happen without him. The Soviets trusted conservative leadership, like Nixon and Reagan's. (USSR was not liberal, it was conservative, too.) They were very leery of liberals. The timing was right, it fit into Gorbachev's policies to get a 'human face' back on the scheme of Communism. And get the USSR check-book out of the Eastern Block nations. Anyway... the real surprise for the followers of conservationism (Reagan, etc.) was the total near to non-violent fall of the Soviet system. None of those folks saw it coming... but some of us scholars did here and over there. I was a US adviser to the Soviet Academy of Science, US and Canadian Studies at that time and those folks knew it was coming. The question was how far would the crumble go..... they didn't expect it to go so far as the dissolution of the entire CCCP "state". Anyway, there are many forces at work in this scenario. With or without Reagan the wall would have come down.

title: You mean a senile American DIDN'T tear down the wall?

content: The leaders of the Soviet Union were not conservative in the sense that they believe in a free market, etc. They were conservative in the sense that they were distrustful of change, and valued the status quo. What Gorbachev, who was much more conservative than people think, realized and expressed was that the status quo was no longer possible. He did not expect, nor want, the revolution that happened. He wanted to reform what already existed in order to allow the soviet state to continue. Reagan, while probably the best president of our lifetimes, was most certainly not the best president in our nation's history. George Washington created the presidency through sheer personality and discretion, making himself "first citizen" and preventing the executive from falling into something akin to monarchy, which many citizens in his time actually wanted.

content: quote: Originally posted by Bleah: ..Reagan, while probably the best president of our lifetimes, was most certainly not the best president in our nation's history. George Washington created the presidency through sheer personality and discretion, making himself "first citizen" and preventing the executive from falling into something akin to monarchy, which many citizens in his time actually wanted. Well said, Bleah. Washington could have been a king. He believed in this nation's founding ideals far too much to seize the authoritarian power he could have had. I also think that Reagan was the greatest president of the latter 20th century, by far. I hope that he's not the greatest president I'll see in my lifetime, but it's starting to look that way, judging from our current president and the last few men who have held that office.
